title: How to Write a Shell Script Using Bash Shell in Ubuntu

steps.title: Launch the Terminal.
steps.content: Launch the Terminal. You can launch the terminal by opening the dash and searching for it by name. You could also open it using the keyboard shortcut Ctrl + Alt + T .

steps.title: Launch the vi or vim editor and create a new script.
steps.content: Launch the vi or vim editor and create a new script. Vim is a free and popular text editor that uses the command line interface. To create a script called ListDir.sh: Type vim ListDir.sh and hit â†µ Enter . Once inside the Editor, type "I" or "i." This will allow you to insert/start typing your shell script.

steps.title: Type the following code:
steps.content: Type the following code: #!/bin/bash . This is known as a Shebang line.

steps.title: Type the code as shown in the figure.
steps.content: Type the code as shown in the figure. The first line (echo "Welcome") prints the line "Welcome" into the terminal. echo is used to return the given text and a new line. The second line (ls) lists the contents of the directory. ls is short for list . The final line (another echo statement) returns the text This completes the list of directories .

steps.title: Exit vim.
steps.content: Exit vim. Type Esc , then : , and then + wq to save and quit. This will write the changes to the file and bring you back to the terminal. Save the file as ListDir.sh

steps.title: Change the permissions.
steps.content: Change the permissions. Enter the following command: chmod +x ListDir.sh . chmod is a command used in Unix like operating systems to change the access permissions to a file.

steps.title: Run the script from the command line.
steps.content: Run the script from the command line. Type ./ListDir.sh to run this script. You should get the list of directories and the message as shown in the above image.
